text: [Intro music]
Hi guys! I'm Laura Vitale
On this episode of Laura in the Kitchen I'm going to show you a recipe that has been so crazy requested
And I'm finally gonna buckle down and make it for you. It's French Macaroons!
I know! Can you believe it?
Ok. So, if you know anything about me then you know that I can't do any recipe
that's tedious and difficult, and I try to simplify every recipe I can for you
so that it's easy for me and easy for you.
So let's go over the ingredients so we can get started.
You're gonna need some ground almond,
confectioner's sugar, egg white
regular sugar, salt, and cream of tartar.
Those are your ingredients to  make the actual little meringue.
The macaroon part.
What a French macaroon is it's two little cookies that are very light and airy
And have a great almondy flavor to them--a natural almond flavor to them
And they're stuffed with anything! It can be
buttercream--traditionally a Swedish buttercream--or a chocolate ganache.
And I'm going to be doing mine with my chocolate ganache, which I have a different episode on that
So go ahead and click on that one if you'd like to see how it's made.
But we'll talk about that a little bit later.
To get started, we're going to sift the ground almonds.
And now if you can't find ground almonds, already ground like this in your supermarket,
All you do is take two cups of blanched almonds--make sure they're peeled the skins off
and then just grind them up in the food processor.
I'll take that and the confectioner's sugar
and we're just going to sift these together.
It's really important that we do this because we don't want any lumps
in our cookies, otherwise they'll bake really unevenly.
That's it. Now we sift this so that we don't get any of these babies left behind
because ground almonds are literally ground up almonds
and there's always going to be some pieces left behind.
so we just want to make sure to get rid of those. Mix these two together
And set those aside.
Now, in a large clean bowl
We're going to add the egg whites,
and start whipping them up. I'm just gonna use my
handy dandy mixer.
I'm going to add salt, and cream of tartar
the moment they start to get frothy.
Which looks perfect.
Mix those up.
Until you get soft peaks.
Now that we have soft peaks, we're going to slowly add
the granulated sugar.
Mix that in.
And continue to whip this until you have nice stiff peaks and the egg whites are beautifully glossy.
That looks perfect.
Now, my grandmother used to say
that you know you have perfectly stiff peaks with the egg whites
If you can just tilt the bowl over your head and nothing falls down, you know you're good to go.
So see? We have stiff peaks.
Now, using a spatula we're going to incorporate our dry mixture here
with the confectioners sugar and ground almonds
We're going to do half of it at a time
And yes, this will deflate the egg whites a little bit
but don't panic.
Just gently fold these in.
And this looks perfect.
Now. Here's what I'm gonna do.
We're gonna take, first of all, two baking sheets or cookie sheets and line them with parchment paper.
Because no matter how nonstick your baking sheets are
it they're not lined with parchment paper, these cookies will stick to the baking sheet.
We don't want that.
Now, if you have a disposable piping bag, great.
But if you don't use this trick.
A large little ziploc bag, like so.
What I'm gonna do is put it in this cup
You gotta give it a little bit of a guide here.
Put one of the corners in first
And just fill this.
See how easy that is?
No one gets dirty, nothing. It's a perfect little trick.
Fill this up with your mixture.
Get it all in there.
Now you can tilt it
Lift it out
And you have your own little bag!
How cool is that?
Now we're going to snip off the bottom corner.
Or one of the bottom corners. About a quarter inch just like that.
Perfect.
I'm gonna show you the size that these need to be.
They need to be about that big.
And you want to do them about an inch and half apart
because they will spread out as they bake.
Now, French macaroons--the traditional ones--
are a lightly golden color and they're absolutely beautiful.
But some fancy shops dye, ya know, the batter.
So if you want to dye the batter to make them a different color, you can do that.
I'm going to stick to the traditional looking French macaroon.
Just go ahead and pipe these out
onto your baking sheet lined with parchment paper.
I think I'm gonna stop about here.
Those are a little bit too close to the edge, but that's ok.
Now, this is a really important step
You need to let these rest for 30 minutes
What happens is, it starts to dry out.
Which is exactly what we want so that when we bake them, they don't fall apart.
And they get a nice crisp exterior with a nice chewy interior.
Which is exactly what a French macaroon should be.
So let these stay just like this for 30 minutes
and meanwhile preheat your oven to 300 degrees F
And get that waiting for you, so that when these have set--and I'll show you what they look like--
we'll bake them.
After 30 minutes, they're nice and dry
and that's exactly what we want.
Now these little peaks, you don't have to. You don't have to push them down.
But you can if you want to.
Now we're going to put these into our preheated oven
at 300 degrees. Make sure it's the top rack or the bottom.
Not the middle--they'll cook unevenly.
I prefer the top rack
And then you're going to , halfway through cooking which will take about 25 minutes
to ge them beautifully light and golden, you're going to turn the baking sheet
because you want them to cook evenly.
So, 15 minutes, turn them.
And cook them for 15 more minutes more or less.
And then we're gonna let them cool completely.
Now let the macaroons cool for about an hour.
They baked for about 30  minutes
and I rotated the sheet pans halfway through
and they're perfect.
Now, if they cracked on the top, it's ok!
If they crack a little bit, that's ok!
They're homemade, ya know. It's not like you're a professional baker
So all I'm gonna do is kinda sandwich them
with some chocolate ganache that I made
And to get the recipe for this, just click on one of my previous episodes.
And they're super simple to do.
Just sandwich them like that.
And that's it.
Put them on a little plate. I'm gonna continue to do all of them
and then we'll dust them with powdered sugar and dig in.
I'm just gonna do this last one for now.
And I'm going to dust them
with confectioner's sugar or powdered sugar.
Whatever you call them.
Look at that! like you've just been to Paris
and you had a French macaroon.
In New Jersey.
I'm gonna take a little bite.
It's so good.
It's got an almond flavor from the ground almonds,
It's like really natural tasting.
It doesn't taste like it's artificial, it's really, really good.
It's got a great texture.
I can see why everyone's crazy with this recipe!
If you want to make them, you know where to get the recipe.
www.laurainthekitchen.com
I'll see you next time. Bye bye!
[Outro music]
